contextId.information: Paul speaks of faith in Christ as if it were a target at which to aim. Paul means that some people are not fulfilling the purpose of their faith, which is to love as he just explained in 1:5. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Some people have missed the mark

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the task of serving God as if it were a place that one could be placed in. AT: "he has assigned me to serve him" or "he has appointed me as his servant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he placed me into service

contextId.information: Paul speaks of God's grace as if it were a liquid that could fill a container and spill out of the top when the container is full. AT: "God showed me much grace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the grace of our Lord overflowed

contextId.information: This speaks about Jesus as if he were a container that holds a liquid. Here "in Christ Jesus" refers to having a relationship with Jesus. AT: "that Christ Jesus enables me to give to God because I am united to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: that is in Christ Jesus

contextId.information: Paul speaks of his instructions as if he could physically put them in front of Timothy. AT: "I am entrusting you with this command" or "This is what I am commanding you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am placing this command before you

contextId.information: Paul speaks of his close relationship to Timothy as though Paul is the father and Timothy is the child. Paul thinks of Timothy as a his child because Paul taught Timothy to have faith in Jesus. AT: "who is truly like my child" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my child

contextId.information: Paul speaks about Timothy working for the Lord as if he were a soldier fighting a battle. AT: "continue to work hard for the Lord" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: engage in the good fight

contextId.information: Paul speaks of these people's faith as if it were a ship that could be wrecked at sea. He means that they have ruined their faith and no longer believe in Jesus. You should use this or a similar metaphor if it will be understood in the project language. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: have been shipwrecked in respect to the faith

contextId.information: Paul speaks as if he physically handed these men to Satan. This probably means that Paul rejected them from the community of believers. Since they are no longer a part of the community, Satan can have power of them and harm them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: whom I gave over to Satan

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the experience of being condemned for having done wrong as if it were a hole that a person could fall into. AT: "have God condemn him as he condemned the devil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: fall into condemnation as the devil

contextId.information: Paul speaks of disgrace as if though it were a hole that a person could fall into. Here "fall into" means to experience. AT: "nothing causes him shame before the unbelievers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he does not fall into disgrace

contextId.information: Paul speaks about these people as if they could say two things at once. He means the person says one thing but mean something else. AT: "not insincere" or "and they must mean what they say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: not double-talkers

contextId.information: "They must continue to believe the true message God revealed to us and that we believe." This refers to a truth that had existed for some time but that God was showing to them at that moment. Paul speaks of true teaching about God as if it were an object that a person could keep with himself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They should keep the revealed truth of the faith

contextId.information: Paul speaks of a person's knowledge that he has done no wrong as if that knowledge or conscience were clean. AT: "knowing they have tried their hardest to do what is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: with a clean conscience

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the group of believers as if they were a family. AT: "as members of God's family" or "among the people of God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in the household of God

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the believers bearing witness to the truth about Christ as if they were a pillar and a base supporting a building. This can be stated as a new sentence. AT: "And, by keeping and teaching God's truth, these members of the church support the truth just as a pillar and base support a building" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: pillar and support of the truth

contextId.information: Paul speaks of people ceasing to trust in Christ as if they were physically leaving a place or an object. AT: "stop trusting in Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: leave the faith

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) Paul is speaking of people who can no longer tell that they are doing wrong as if their minds are ruined like skin that someone has burnt with a hot iron or 2) Paul is speaking of these people as if Satan had put a mark on these people with a hot iron to indicate that they belong to him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Their own consciences will be branded

contextId.information: Paul speaks of his instructions as if they were objects that could be physically presented to the believers. Here, to place before means to instruct or to remind. AT: "If you help the believers remember these things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: If you place these things before the brothers

contextId.information: Paul speaks of God's word and its' teaching as if it could physically feed Timothy and make him strong. This can be stated in active form. AT: "the words of faith and the good teaching that you have followed are causing you to trust more strongly in Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: you are being nourished by the words of faith and by the good teaching that you have followed

contextId.information: This is probably an expression that means "silly" or "absurd." Paul is not purposely insulting women in his reference to "old women." Instead, he and his audience knew that men die younger than women, so there are more women than men whose minds have become feeble due to old age. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: loved by old women

contextId.information: Paul speaks of Timothy as if he were a container that could hold God's gifts. This can be stated in positive form. AT: "Do not neglect your spiritual gift" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Do not neglect the gift that is in you

contextId.information: Paul speaks of God's gifts to Timothy as if he could physically be in them. AT: "Do all these things and live according to them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Care for these things. Be in them

contextId.information: Paul speaks of Timothy's increasing ability to serve God as if it were a physical object that others could look at. AT: "so other people will know that you are serving God better and better" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so that your progress may be evident to all people

contextId.information: Paul speaks about people who do not seek to please God as if they were dead. AT: "is like a dead person, she does not respond to God" (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: is dead

contextId.information: Paul speaks of living in faithfulness to Christ as if it were a path to be followed. This means the woman stopped obeying Jesus and started obeying Satan. AT: "left the path of Christ to follow Satan" or "decided to obey Satan instead of Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: turned aside after Satan

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the community having to help more people than they are able as if they were carrying too much weight on their backs. This can be stated in active form. AT: "so that the Christian community will not have to help widows whose families could provide for them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: so that the church will not be weighed down

contextId.information: Paul speaks about the word as if it is an object which a person can work with. AT: "those who preach and teach God's word" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: those who work with the word and in teaching

contextId.information: Paul is using this quotation as a metaphor meaning that church leaders deserve to receive payment from the Christian community for their work. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You shall not put a muzzle on an ox while it treads the grain

contextId.information: Paul speaks of accusations as if they were objects that could be physically accepted by people. AT: "Do not accept as true any accusation that someone speaks" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Do not receive an accusation

contextId.information: Paul speaks of someone's sin as if it were an object that could be shared with others. AT: "do not join in another person's sin" or "do not participate when another person sins"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Do not share in the sins of another person

contextId.information: Paul speaks of sins as if they were objects that someone could hide. This can be stated in active form. AT: "but people will later find out about even the good deeds that are not obvious" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: but even the others cannot be hidden

contextId.information: Paul speaks of people working as slaves as if they are oxen carrying a yoke. AT: "Let all who are working as slaves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Let all who are under the yoke as slaves

contextId.information: Paul speaks of people who feel compelled to engage in useless arguments as if they were ill. Such people greatly desire the act of arguing itself, and do not really want to find a way to agree. AT: "all he wants to do is argue" or "he craves arguments" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he is sick with controversies and arguments

contextId.information: Paul speaks about those who let the temptation of money cause them to sin as if they are animals that have fallen into a hole that a hunter has used as a trap. AT: "to become wealthy will encounter more temptation than they can resist, and they will be like an animal in a trap (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to become wealthy fall into temptation, into a trap

contextId.information: Paul speaks about those that let sin destroy them as if they are a boat that sinks under the water. AT: "and into other kinds of evil that ruin and destroy a person like a boat sinking under the water" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and into whatever else makes people sink into ruin and destruction

contextId.information: Paul speaks of wrong desires as if they were evil guides who intentionally guide people down the wrong path. This can be stated in active form. AT: "have let their desires lead them away from the truth" or "have stopped believing the truth"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: have been mislead away from the faith

contextId.information: Paul speaks of these temptations and sins as if they were things that a person could physically run away from. AT: "treat these things like creatures who want to harm you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: flee from these things

contextId.information: "Run after" or "Chase." Paul speaks of righteousness and other good qualities as if they were things that a person could run after.This idiom is the opposite of "flee from." It means to try your best to obtain something. AT: "Seek to gain" or "Do your best to act in" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Pursue righteousness

contextId.information: This continues the metaphor. Paul speaks about a person receiving eternal life as if they are a victorious athlete or warrior taking their prize. AT: "Take eternal life as your reward as a victorious athlete takes his prize" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Take hold of the everlasting life

contextId.information: Paul speaks of spiritual blessings as if they were earthly wealth. AT: "serve and help others in many ways" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: be rich in good works

contextId.information: Here Paul speaks about God's blessings that he gives in heaven as if they are riches that a person is storing away for later use. AT: "they will have a large amount of blessings from Christ when he returns" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they will store up for themselves a good foundation for what is to come
